subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 1846
msgSnippet: ... Yes, and for that reason, I don t think Agitar will make a code base more TDD-able if that code base doesn t have this quality in the first place.
messageBody:
On 6/1/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
> Do you think that a tool like Agitar would be useful in those
> situations where TDD is not? I have trouble with this because if
> Agitar can make observations then humans could write tests.


Yes, and for that reason, I don't think Agitar will make a code base "more
TDD-able" if that code base doesn't have this quality in the first place.

Actually I disagree with the use of the term 'many' and 'sometimes'.
> It is always possible to write tests first. The question is whether
> it is always practical.


Fair point, and I agree. If the cost of doing TDD is more expensive than
doing "regular" testing, it doesn't make sense to pick TDD (assuming that
the final product will have the same quality either way).

Some of the situations I have encountered in the past and the present where
TDD is not a practical choice are GUI or mobile developments (something I do
a lot these days). I also work fairly regularly with very large code bases
that have grown organically over several years, and again, practicing TDD at
this level would cost a lot more than doing things traditionally.

Of course, I make it a point in these circumstances to try and improve the
situation as I go along, but again, it's not always obvious to choose
between a new feature and a cosmetic refactoring that might improve your
code base down the line.

This is why I like to work on open-source projects on the side: it feels
like a breath of fresh air where your imagination and your principles can be
law :-)

--
Cédric
